citations.narrative:
The facility is missing the acquisition date for 1 peahen, 5 chickens and 1 goose. Acquisition information is necessary for
APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals still at the facility during inspection and to properly trace their
movements.
Each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. These
records shall include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired from, the USDA license
or registration number of the person if they are licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and state and the
driver's license number and state of the person if they are not licensed under the Act, the name and address of the person
to whom an animal was sold or given to, the date of the purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of the animal, the species
of the animal, and the number of animals in the shipment.
The facility must maintain a record of disposition for the animals and ensure all required information is properly and
accurately documented at all times.

There was a excess presence of flies in the domestic pig enclosure, domestic cattle enclosure and the cat enclosure, the
majority being in the pig enclosure. Additionally, the alpaca "Curly" has flies present on her ear wounds. While the facility
does have fly bags up near the pig enclosure, they do not seem to be effective. The excess presence of flies may cause
discomfort and increase the risk of disease hazards. An appropriate and effective program for fly control shall be
established and maintained to provide for the health and well-being of the animals.
To be corrected by: 21-September-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is missing the acquisition date for 1 peahen, 5 chickens and 1 goose. Acquisition information is necessary for 
APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals still at the facility during inspection and to properly trace their 
movements. 
Each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. These 
records shall include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired from, the USDA license 
or registration number of the person if they are licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and state and the 
driver's license number and state of the person if they are not licensed under the Act, the name and address of the person 
to whom an animal was sold or given to, the date of the purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of the animal, the species 
of the animal, and the number of animals in the shipment. 
The facility must maintain a record of disposition for the animals and ensure all required information is properly and 
accurately documented at all times. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
There was a excess presence of flies in the domestic pig enclosure, domestic cattle enclosure and the cat enclosure, the 
majority being in the pig enclosure. Additionally, the alpaca "Curly" has flies present on her ear wounds. While the facility 
does have fly bags up near the pig enclosure, they do not seem to be effective. The excess presence of flies may cause 
discomfort and increase the risk of disease hazards. An appropriate and effective program for fly control shall be 
established and maintained to provide for the health and well-being of the animals. 
To be corrected by: 21-September-2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
